questions.text: A 28 year old male presents with a painless, firm testicular mass. Ultrasound confirms a solid intratesticular lesion, and tumor markers are elevated. A CT scan reveals retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy without distant metastasis. According to the TNM staging system, what is the stage of this testicular tumor?
questions.solution:
TNM Staging of Testicular Tumor

  • A solid testicular lump that cannot be felt separately from the testis may be a malignant tumor.
  • Lymphatic spread is to the para-aortic lymph nodes.
  • Ultrasound is a mandatory investigation in all cases of suspected testicular tumour .
  • Tumour markers (AFP, HCG and LDH) should be measured prior to orchiectomy.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. T1N0M0: Incorrect. Indicates tumor limited to the testis and epididymis without lymphovascular invasion and no lymph node involvement.

Option B. T2N1M0: Correct. T2 includes tumor with lymphovascular invasion, and N1 indicates retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis <2 cm.

Option C. T3N0M0: Incorrect. T3 denotes tumor invasion into the spermatic cord.

Option D. T1N1M1: Incorrect. M1 indicates distant metastasis, which is not present.

Key Points:

  • T2N1M0 indicates a tumor with lymphovascular invasion and retroperitoneal lymph node involvement <2 cm.

questions.text: According to the World Health Organization (WHO) classification, which of the following is considered a germ cell tumor of the testis?
questions.solution:
Classification and Pathology of Testicular Tumors

  • Types of Testicular Tumors:
    • Germ Cell Tumors (GCTs) (90-95%): Includes seminoma, embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac tumor, teratoma, and choriocarcinoma.
    • Sex Cord-Stromal Tumors (1-2%): Includes Leydig cell tumors.
    • Lymphoma (3-7%): Common in older adults.
    • Other Tumors (1-2%): Rare types.
  • Seminoma:
    • Appearance: Homogeneous, pinkish cream color, compresses adjacent tissue.
    • Histology: Oval cells with clear cytoplasm, large nuclei, separated by fibrous stroma.
    • Metastasis: Primarily through lymphatics, rare hematogenous spread.
    • Common Age Group: Young adults; rare in children and men over 70.
  • Non-Seminomatous Germ Cell Tumors (NSGCTs):
    • Embryonal Carcinoma: Highly malignant, may invade cord structures.
    • Yolk Sac Tumor: Produces alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), common in children.
    • Teratoma: Contains tissues from ectoderm, endoderm, and mesoderm. Can metastasize.
    • Choriocarcinoma: Produces HCG, highly malignant, early metastasis via lymphatics and blood.
  • Spermatocytic Seminoma: Distinct from seminoma, occurs in men over 50, rarely metastasizes. Treatment typically involves orchidectomy.
  • Sex Cord-Stromal Tumors:
    • Leydig Cell Tumor: Most common sex cord-stromal tumor, usually benign, can become malignant (10% cases).
    • Sertoli Cell Tumor: Rare, may be associated with genetic syndromes, malignancy in 10-22% of cases.
    • Granulosa Cell Tumor: Very rare in adults, juvenile type seen in children.
  • Mixed Germ Cell/Sex Cord Tumors:
    • Gonadoblastoma:
    • Found in patients with mixed gonadal dysgenesis, associated with cryptorchidism and other genital anomalies.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Leydig cell tumor: Incorrect. These are sex cord stromal tumors, not germ cell tumors

Option B. Sertoli cell tumor: Incorrect. Sertoli cell tumors fall under sex cord stromal tumors.

Option C. Seminoma: Correct. Seminomas are a type of germ cell tumor, classified by WHO as a distinct subtype of testicular cancer.

Option D. Adenomatoid tumor: Incorrect. These are benign para testicular tumors, not germ cell in origin.

Key Points:

  • Seminomas are the most common GCT, typically spread via lymphatics.
  • Sex Cord-Stromal Tumors are rare but can be associated with genetic syndromes. Mixed tumors like gonadoblastomas occur in individuals with gonadal dysgenesis.

questions.text: Which tumor marker is most commonly elevated in nonseminomatous germ cell tumors (NSGCTs)?
questions.solution:
Tumor Markers in Testicular Germ Cell Tumors

  • Seminomas: Beta human chorionic gonadotropin (βhCG) may be elevated; AFP is typically normal.
  • Nonseminomatous Germ Cell Tumors (NSGCTs):
    • AFP: Elevated in yolk sac tumors and embryonal carcinoma.
    • βhCG: Elevated in choriocarcinoma and some embryonal carcinomas.
    • LDH(Lactate Dehydrogenase): Used to assess tumor burden and prognosis.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Alphafetoprotein (AFP): Correct. AFP is commonly elevated in nonseminomatous germ cell tumors, such as yolk sac tumors and embryonal carcinoma.

Option B. Prostate specific antigen (PSA): Incorrect. PSA is a marker used in prostate cancer, not testicular germ cell tumors.

Option C. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA): Incorrect. CEA is a marker for colorectal cancer and some other carcinomas but is not specific for testicular tumors.

Option D. CA125: Incorrect. CA125 is primarily used as a marker for ovarian cancer

Key Points:

  • AFP is a key marker for nonseminomatous germ cell tumors.
  • βhCG can be elevated in both seminomas and NSGCTs, depending on the subtype.

choices.text: Immediate chemotherapy with BEP regimen (Bleomycin, Etoposide, Cisplatin)
Radiotherapy to the paraaortic lymph nodes
High-dose radiation to the pelvis and abdomen

questions.text: A 30 year old male diagnosed with stage I seminoma ( tumor size 2 cm )has undergone radical orchiectomy. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Treatment of Testicular Tumor

  • Surgery: Radical Orchidectomy
    • Procedure: Performed via an inguinal
    • The spermatic cord is clamped to prevent the spread of cancer cells. The cord is then double-transfixed and divided at the internal inguinal ring before the testis is removed.
    • Purpose: Essential for staging and histological diagnosis of germ cell tumors (GCTs)
  • Management Based on Stage:
    • Non-Metastatic Disease (Stage I):Seminoma:
      • Surveillance:
        • Suitable for low-risk patients (tumor <4 cm, no stromal rete testis invasion).
      • Adjuvant Chemotherapy: One course of carboplatin offers similar outcomes to radiotherapy with less long-term toxicity.
      • Adjuvant Radiotherapy: Targets para-aortic or iliac nodes;
  • NSGCT:
    • Surveillance: Option for well-informed, compliant patients; relapse rate high.
    • Adjuvant Chemotherapy: One cycle of BEP reduces recurrence to ~3%.
    • RPLND (Retroperitoneal Lymph Node Dissection):
  • Metastatic Disease (Stages II and III):
    • Chemotherapy: Mainstay treatment for metastatic testicular cancer.Regimen: BEP (Bleomycin, Etoposide, Cisplatin) or EP (Etoposide, Cisplatin) for seminomas and NSGCTs.
    • Radiotherapy: Previously used for early-stage II seminoma; now less favored due to risks of cardiovascular issues and secondary malignancies.
    • Surgery (RPLND): Considered for postpubertal teratomas without elevated tumor markers.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Surveillance with regular follow-ups: Correct. For stage I seminoma, surveillance is a recommended option post orchiectomy due to the high cure rates and low risk of recurrence.

Option B. Immediate chemotherapy with BEP regimen: Incorrect. Chemotherapy is usually reserved for higher-stage disease or if surveillance reveals recurrence.

Option C. Radiotherapy to the paraaortic lymph nodes: Incorrect. Although radiotherapy is an option, it is not immediately necessary for all patients and is typically reserved for those not opting for surveillance.

Option D. High dose radiation to the pelvis and abdomen: Incorrect. Such extensive radiation is not indicated for stage I seminoma

Key Points:

  • Radical Orchidectomy: Standard procedure for diagnosis and initial management.
  • Metastatic Disease: Primarily treated with chemotherapy; surgical options for specific cases.

questions.text: Which anatomical structure is primarily responsible for guiding the descent of the testis from the abdomen to the scrotum during embryonic development?
questions.solution:
Embryology of Testicular Descent

  • Descent Process: Testes descend from the abdomen into the scrotum through the inguinal canal, guided by the gubernaculum.
  • Timing: Descent typically occurs between 7th and 9th months of gestation.
  • Hormonal Influence: Androgens play a crucial role in stimulating testicular descent.
  • Clinical Significance: Failure of descent results in cryptorchidism (undescended testes), which may lead to infertility and increased risk of malignancy.
  • Testes that are absent from the scrotum after 3 months of age are unlikely to descend
  • Histological changes in the testis can be seen from 1 year of age
  • An incompletely descended testis tends to atrophy as puberty approaches
  • Boys with undescended testes are at greater risk of infertility, testicular malignancy, hernia and torsion

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Spermatic cord: Incorrect. The spermatic cord contains vas deferens, blood vessels, and nerves but does not guide testicular descent.

Option B. Tunica albuginea: Incorrect. This is a fibrous capsule surrounding the testis, not involved in its descent.

Option C. Gubernaculum: Correct. The gubernaculum is a structure that guides the descent of the testis from the abdomen to the scrotum during fetal development.

Option D. Epididymis: Incorrect. The epididymis is involved in sperm storage and maturation, not testicular descent.

Key Points:

  • The gubernaculum is key in guiding testicular descent.

questions.text: A 4 year old boy is diagnosed with bilateral undescended testis. Which of the following is a common long term complication if left untreated?
questions.solution:
Consequences of Undescended Testes

  • Infertility:
    • Men with undescended testes may have reduced fertility, even after orchidopexy.
    • Unilateral Cases: Infertility rate similar to the general population.
    • Late Orchidopexy (in Adults): Almost always results in infertility and azoospermia.
    • Early Surgery: Recommended to prevent degeneration of spermatogenic tissue, which starts after the second year of life.
  • Malignancy:
    • Risk of testicular cancer is 2-6 times
    • Most common type of cancer in untreated undescended testes is seminoma, with a peak incidence between ages 15-45.
    • Early detection through testicular self-examination is crucial.
  • Hernia:
    • About 90% of boys with undescended testes have a patent processus vaginalis, increasing the risk of hernia, though not all develop a clinically apparent hernia.
  • Testicular Torsion:
    • Undescended testes have a higher risk of torsion due to developmental abnormalities between the testis and its mesentery.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Hydrocele: Incorrect. Hydrocele is unrelated to undescended testes and involves fluid accumulation in the scrotum.

Option B. Testicular torsion: Incorrect. While torsion is more common in undescended testes, it is not the most significant longterm complication.

Option C. Testicular cancer: Correct. There is an increased risk of developing testicular cancer in undescended testes, particularly if not corrected by early childhood.

Option D. Varicocele: Incorrect. Varicocele involves dilated veins in the scrotum and is not directly associated with undescended testes.

Key Points:

  • Undescended testes increase the risk of testicular cancer and infertility.
  • Early surgical correction (orchidopexy) reduces risks.

questions.text: What is the recommended age for performing orchidopexy in a child with unilateral undescended testis?
questions.solution:
Treatment of Undescended Testes

  • Orchidopexy:
    • Timing: Performed between6 and 18 months of age to prevent complications (e.g., infertility, malignancy).Corrected age is considered for premature babies.
    • Access through a short incision over the deep inguinal ring.
    • Division of the external oblique aponeurosis to expose the inguinal canal.
    • Key Manoeuvres to Gain Length:
      • Separate and ligate the patent processus vaginalis.
      • Divide coverings of the spermatic cord, including the cremasteric muscle.
      • Divide lateral fibrous bands inside the internal inguinal ring.
    • Placement: The testis is placed in a pouch between the dartos muscle and skin of the scrotum.
  • Orchidectomy:
    • Considered for atrophic or potentially malignant testes, especially in postpubertal boys with a normal contralateral testis.
  • Management of Impalpable Testes:
    • Diagnostic Laparoscopy:

Recommended if the testes are not palpable under anesthesia.

  • Laparoscopic Orchidopexy:
    • Testis is mobilized using a triangular pedicle of vessels and the vas.
    • Fowler-Stephens Orchidopexy: Dividing vessels for better positioning;can be done in one or two stages to allow collateral vessel development.
    • Two-Stage Procedure: Allows 6 months for collateral development before final positioning.
  • If No Testis is Found:
    • Determine presence of blind-ending vessels or a testicular nubbin.Follow vessels through internal ring for scrotal exploration to locate potential testicular remnants.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. At birth: Incorrect. Surgery is not performed immediately after birth as spontaneous descent can occur.

Option B. 6-12 months: Correct. Early orchidopexy is recommended within this age range to reduce the risk of complications like cancer and infertility.

Option C. 2-3 years: Incorrect. Surgery is ideally performed earlier to minimize risks.

Option D. Only after puberty: Incorrect. Delayed surgery increases risks of malignancy and infertility.

Key Points:

  • Laparoscopy is valuable for managing non-palpable testes and may involve single or staged procedures to optimise outcomes.
  • Orchidectomy is considered for atrophic or high-risk testes, especially post puberty
  • Orchidopexy is ideally performed between 612 months of age.

questions.text: A 15 year old boy presents with a sudden onset of severe scrotal pain, swelling, and nausea. The affected testis is high riding with an absent cremasteric reflex. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Torsion of Testes

  • Twisting of the spermatic cord leading to ischemia and necrosis if untreated.
  • Symptoms: Acute onset of severe scrotal pain, swelling, nausea, vomiting, high riding testis, absent cremasteric reflex.
  • Diagnosis: Primarily clinical; Doppler ultrasound to confirm blood flow disruption.
  • Management: Surgical detorsion and fixation (orchidopexy) within 6 hours to save the testis.
  • Bilateral orchidopexy advised.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Epididymitis: Incorrect. Epididymitis is usually associated with gradual pain, fever, and urinary symptoms, with a positive cremasteric reflex.

Option B. Testicular torsion: Correct. Sudden severe pain, highriding testis, and absence of the cremasteric reflex are classic signs of testicular torsion.

Option C. Hydrocele: Incorrect. Hydrocele typically presents with painless scrotal swelling.

Option D. Varicocele: Incorrect. Varicocele causes a dull ache and "bag of worms" appearance, not acute pain and swelling.

Key Points:

  • Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency requiring prompt intervention.
  • Highriding testis and absent cremasteric reflex are diagnostic clues.

questions.text: A 20 year old male complains of a dull ache in the left scrotum, especially after standing for long periods. Physical examination shows a mass resembling a "bag of worms" above the left testis, which increases with Valsalva manoeuvre. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Varicocele

  • Dilation of the pampiniform plexus veins, more common on the left side.
  • There are three theories as to the cause of varicoceles:
    • The absence or failure of the anti reflux valve usually located where the testicular vein joins the left renal vein or the inferior vena cava on the right. This causes reflux and retrograde flow in the testicular vein.
    • The "nutcracker"effect that occurs when the left testicular vein gets trapped between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta. This causes venous compression and testicular vein obstruction.
    • Angulation at the junction of the left testicular vein and the left renal vein.
  • Symptoms:
    • Dull, aching pain, especially after prolonged standing; may be asymptomatic; described as feeling like a "bag of worms."
  • Diagnosis: Physical exam with Valsalva maneuver, confirmed by ultrasound showing dilated veins >3 mm.
  • Management:
    • Conservative in asymptomatic cases;
    • surgical ligation or embolization in symptomatic cases or infertility.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Hydrocele: Incorrect. Hydrocele presents as a painless fluid filled sac around the testis, not a "bag of worms" appearance.

Option B. Varicocele: Correct. Varicocele involves dilated veins of the pampiniform plexus, often described as a "bag of worms" and typically worsens with standing or Valsalva maneuver.

Option C. Testicular torsion: Incorrect. Torsion presents with acute pain and high-riding testis, not a mass that feels like a "bag of worms."

Option D. Epididymal cyst: Incorrect. These cysts are typically painless and do not present with a "bag of worms" feel.

Key Points:

  • Varicocele is a common cause of male infertility and presents as a "bag of worms" on palpation.
  • Surgical treatment is considered for symptomatic relief or in cases of infertility.

choices.text: Grade I: Palpable with Valsalva, Grade II: Palpable without Valsalva, Grade III: Visible without palpation
Grade I: Visible on ultrasound, Grade II: Palpable only during Valsalva, Grade III: Always palpable
Grade I: Small, Grade II: Moderate, Grade III: Large
Grade I: Asymptomatic, Grade II: Symptomatic, Grade III: Requires surgery

questions.text: How is varicocele commonly classified based on physical examination findings?
questions.solution:
Varicocele Classification

Grade I: palpable only during Valsalva maneuver.

Grade II: palpable without Valsalva but not visible.

Grade III: visible through the scrotal skin without palpation.

  • Higher grades may correlate with symptoms and impact on fertility.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Grade I: Palpable with Valsalva, Grade II: Palpable without Valsalva, Grade III: Visible without palpation: Correct. This is the standard clinical grading of varicocele based on examination.

Option B. Grade I: Visible on ultrasound, Grade II: Palpable only during Valsalva, Grade III: Always palpable: Incorrect. This classification does not align with standard clinical grading.

Option C. Grade I: Small, Grade II: Moderate, Grade III: Large: Incorrect. While size can correlate with grade, this is not the standard grading method.

Option D. Grade I: Asymptomatic, Grade II: Symptomatic, Grade III: Requires surgery: Incorrect. Grading is based on palpability and visibility, not symptoms or treatment needs.

Key Points:

  • Varicocele classification is based on physical examination findings.
  • Higher Grade varicoceles are more likely to be symptomatic and affect fertility.

choices.text: Collection of fluid around the testis due to trauma
Fluid collection in the scrotum due to a patent processus vaginalis
Hydrocele that develops secondary to infection
Fluid accumulation between the layers of the tunica vaginalis after surgery

questions.text: Which of the following best describes a communicating hydrocele?
questions.solution:
Types of Hydrocele

  • Hydrocele is an abnormal collection of serous fluid within the processus vaginalis, typically around the testis (tunica vaginalis) or along the spermatic cord.
  • Communicating Hydrocele:
    • Due to a patent processus vaginalis, allowing peritoneal fluid to flow into the scrotum; often associated with indirect inguinal hernias.
  • Non-Communicating Hydrocele:
    • No communication with the peritoneal cavity; fluid accumulates due to excessive production or defective absorption by the tunica vaginalis.
    • Most common type, also known as primary hydrocele.
  • Infantile Hydrocele:
    • Partial closure of the processus vaginalis, with fluid trapped in the middle portion or along the cord.
  • Secondary Hydrocele:
    • Occurs in men over 40, often due to injury, infection, neoplasm, or radiation therapy.
  • Incidence and Pathophysiology:Affects about 1% of adult men. More than 80% of newborns have a patent processus vaginalis, which usually closes by 18 months of age.
  • Symptoms
    • painless scrotal swelling with transillumination.
    • Bilateral hydroceles may be associated with ascites.
    • Hydrocele of the cord is an oval swelling near the spermatic cord, which can mimic an inguinal hernia.
    • In females, a hydrocele of the canal of Nuck is related to the round ligament and partially within the inguinal canal.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Collection of fluid around the testis due to trauma: Incorrect. This describes a reactive hydrocele, which is not congenital.

Option B. Fluid collection in the scrotum due to a patent processus vaginalis: Correct. Congenital hydroceles occur when the processus vaginalis remains patent, allowing peritoneal fluid to flow into the scrotum.

Option C. Hydrocele that develops secondary to infection: Incorrect. This describes a secondary or reactive hydrocele.

Option D. Fluid accumulation between the layers of the tunica vaginalis after surgery: Incorrect. This could describe a secondary hydrocele but is not congenital.

Key Points:

  • Hydroceles are classified based on their communication with the peritoneal cavity and can be primary (most common) or secondary (related to underlying conditions).

questions.text: A 40 year old male presents with a large, noncommunicating hydrocele that is causing discomfort and cosmetic concern. He undergoes surgery for hydrocele repair. Which of the following is the most appropriate surgical approach for this patient?
questions.solution:
Types of Hydrocele Surgery

  1. Hydrocelectomy (Jaboulay's Procedure):

Indication: Large, symptomatic hydroceles.

Procedure: Excision and eversion of the hydrocele sac to prevent recurrence.

Outcome: Effective in reducing hydrocele size and recurrence risk.

  1. Lord's Procedure:

Indication: Smaller, uncomplicated hydroceles.

Procedure: Plication of the hydrocele sac without complete excision.

Outcome: Less invasive, shorter recovery, but not suitable for large hydroceles.

  1. Aspiration and Sclerotherapy:

Indication: Temporary relief or patients unfit for surgery.

Procedure: Aspiration of hydrocele fluid followed by sclerosant injection.

Outcome: High recurrence and infection rates; not a definitive treatment.

  1. High Ligation of the Sac (Herniotomy):

Indication: Paediatric hydroceles, particularly when associated with a patent processus vaginalis.

Procedure: Ligation of the processus vaginalis at the internal ring.

Outcome: Commonly used for pediatric patients; not suitable for adults.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Jaboulay's procedure: Correct. Hydrocelectomy is the preferred surgical method for treating large, noncommunicating hydroceles in adults. It involves excising and everting the hydrocele sac to prevent fluid reaccumulation.

Option B. Lord's procedure: Incorrect. Lord's procedure involves plication of the hydrocele sac and is typically used for smaller, uncomplicated hydroceles. It is not commonly used for large hydroceles.

Option C. Aspiration and sclerotherapy: Incorrect. This method is less invasive and used for temporary relief or when surgery is contraindicated. It is not a definitive treatment for large hydroceles due to the risk of recurrence and infection.

Option D. High ligation of the sac (Herniotomy): Incorrect. This procedure is commonly used to treat paediatric hydroceles associated with a patent processus vaginalis, not suitable for adult hydroceles.

Key Points: Hydrocelectomy is the preferred method for treating large hydroceles in adults.

choices.text: Epididymal cysts are fluid filled, whereas spermatoceles contain sperm
Spermatoceles are always painful, while epididymal cysts are not
Epididymal cysts typically occur in older men, while spermatoceles are seen in younger men
Spermatoceles require surgical intervention, whereas epididymal cysts do not

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly differentiates an epididymal cyst from a spermatocele?
questions.solution:
Epididymal Cyst vs. Spermatocele

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Epididymal cysts are fluid filled, whereas spermatoceles contain sperm: Correct. Epididymal cysts contain clear serous fluid, while spermatoceles contain milky fluid rich in spermatozoa.

Option B. Spermatoceles are always painful, while epididymal cysts are not: Incorrect. Both are usually painless.

Option C. Epididymal cysts typically occur in older men, while spermatoceles are seen in younger men: Incorrect. Both can occur in men of various ages.

Option D. Spermatoceles require surgical intervention, whereas epididymal cysts do not: Incorrect. Both are usually managed conservatively unless symptomatic or causing discomfort.

Key Points:

  • Epididymal cysts contain clear fluid, while spermatoceles contain sperm rich fluid.
  • Both are typically managed conservatively unless symptoms are present.

questions.text: A 35 year old male presents with acute onset scrotal pain, swelling, and fever. Physical examination reveals a tender, swollen testis with an erythematous scrotum. Doppler ultrasound shows increased blood flow to the testis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Epididymo-Orchitis

  • Epididymitis: Inflammation confined to the epididymis, often precedes epididymo-orchitis.
  • Epididymo-orchitis: Inflammation involving both epididymis and testis.
  • Pathophysiology
    • Infection reaches the epididymis through the vas deferens from the urethra, prostate, or seminal vesicles.
    • Young men: Most common cause is Chlamydia trachomatis; Neisseria gonorrhoeae less frequent.
    • Older men: Often due to urinary tract infections (UTI) or indwelling catheters, related to high pressure in prostatic urethra.
  • Clinical Features
    • Symptoms may start with urinary or genital infection. Presentation: Painful swelling of the epididymis and testis, scrotal redness, fever, groin ache.Scrotal wall may become adherent to epididymis.
  • Complications
    • Abscess formation, testicular infarction, atrophy, chronic inflammation, infertility.
  • Investigation
    • Urethral swab: For culture and nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) for Chlamydia and Gonorrhoea.
    • Urinalysis: Leukocytes presence, possible UTI.
    • Scrotal Ultrasound: Useful to detect abscess or differentiate from testicular torsion.
  • Differential Diagnosis
    • Testicular torsion: Requires urgent surgical exploration if suspected.
  • Treatment
    • Empiric antibiotic therapy based on likely pathogens:
      • STI-related (e.g., young men): Ceftriaxone IM + Doxycycline for 10 days.
      • STI + enteric organisms (e.g., men practising anal sex): Ceftriaxone IM + Levofloxacin for 10 days.
      • Enteric organisms (e.g., older men): Levofloxacin for 10 days.
    • Abscess formation: Requires drainage.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Testicular torsion: Incorrect. Torsion usually presents with sudden onset severe pain, a highriding testis, and absent blood flow on Doppler ultrasound.

Option B. Epididymo Orchitis: Correct. Acute scrotal pain, swelling, fever, and increased blood flow on Doppler ultrasound are indicative of epididymo orchitis.

Option C. Hydrocele: Incorrect. Hydrocele presents with painless scrotal swelling, not acute pain or systemic symptoms.

Option D. Varicocele: Incorrect. Varicocele causes a dull ache and a "bag of worms" feel, typically without acute symptoms or systemic involvement.

Key Points:

  • Epididymo orchitis presents with acute scrotal pain, swelling, and fever.
  • Increased blood flow on Doppler ultrasound helps differentiate it from testicular torsion.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of cancer?
questions.solution:
Scrotal Cancer

  • Most Common Type:
    • Squamous cell carcinoma, associated with occupational exposure to tar, soot, and oils (g., chimney sweeps).
  • Risk Factors:
    • Chronic irritation, poor hygiene, HPV infection, previous radiation.
  • Symptoms:
    • Painless lump, ulceration, nonhealing sore on the scrotum.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Biopsy confirms diagnosis. Imaging to assess spread.
  • Management:
    • Surgical excision with clear margins, inguinal lymph node dissection if indicated, radiotherapy for advanced cases.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Basal cell carcinoma: Incorrect. Basal cell carcinoma is common on sun exposed skin but rare on the scrotum.

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: Correct. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of scrotal cancer, often linked to chronic irritation or exposure to carcinogens.

Option C. Melanoma: Incorrect. Melanoma can occur on the scrotum but is less common than squamous cell carcinoma.

Option D. Adenocarcinoma: Incorrect. Adenocarcinoma is not typically seen in the scrotal region.

Key Points:

  • Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common scrotal malignancy.
  • Occupational exposure to carcinogens is a significant risk factor.
